greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of maximal chains of factorizations of n into factors > 1, ordered by refinement.
comment: If x and y are factorizations of the same integer and it is possible to produce x by further factoring the factors of y, flattening, and sorting, then x <= y.
a(n) depends only on prime signature of n (cf. A025487). - _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 08 2018
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..11520
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..100000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
program: A064988(n) = { my(f = factor(n)); for (k=1, #f~, f[k, 1] = prime(f[k, 1]); ); factorback(f); }; \\ From A064988

A320105(n) = if(bigomega(n)<=2,1,if(mapisdefined(memoA320105,n), mapget(memoA320105,n), my(f=factor(n), u = #f~, s = 0); for(i=1,u,for(j=i+(1==f[i,2]),u, s += A320105(prime(primepi(f[i,1])*primepi(f[j,1]))*(n/(f[i,1]*f[j,1]))))); mapput(memoA320105,n,s); (s)));
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Jul 22 2018
ext: Data section extended to 105 terms by _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 08 2018
